I'm responding to Ian Maitland and Lori below:

From an article just a week or so in Forbes magazine, primary care physicians earn an average of $186,000 per year. The average salary in America is $68,888 per year when both husband AND wife are working.

Many scientists are happy to make far less than the $186,000 which GP's make in America. We also had rigorous post-graduate training -- and we work long hard hours. The typical PhD in physics starts at ~$55,000 per year. A research physicist starts at $43,000 per year. Only top senior research staff in physics will eventually have a salary which is comparable to a GP's salary. Yet such a researcher has to have highly specialized skills and creativity. Indeed, they frequently are the ones who make the scientific breakthroughs which then allow the physicians to make such high salaries.

Why the discrepancy? I do not think it is because the physicists are being underpaid.

By way of background: My dad read to me every single day until I was 13 or 14 (kid's books to poetry to Sherlock Holmes to Les Miserables), and I was also an avid reader from the age of 5. I listened to a million audio books, from Jim Weiss to the full "Three Musketeers." I had a college level reading ability by the time I started high school, and an innate sense of how language worked. I'm now in law school.

I think reading to children and young adults - preferably by a parent or "live" person who can modify their reading based on the child, but also using audiobooks when a person is not available - allows them to HEAR what the language should be. A good out-loud reader reads punctuation differently, and you can hear how it should look. While a mix of audio and printed word is best, I don't think we should underestimate the ability of an audiobook to teach children sentence structure, the meaning of words within the context or because of the reader's vocal inflection (which can increase vocabulary), or anything else they supposedly receive by being forced to read the printed book.

I took Spanish in junior high school and high school, and in 10th grade I added Latin. That class was composed of two groups of students: those who had a good command of Spanish or French and those who had failed these spoken languages and were taking Latin because they would not have to talk.

Studying Latin taught me discipline and order -- declensions and conjugations -- plus grammar -- direct and indirect objects, commands, etc.

Two years of middle school Latin would provide rigor to all students and set a foundation for subsequent study of (European) languages.

Jameson's comment about the building a foundation of roots for study of Mandarin and Arabic supports this idea.

By the way, it was a thrill to read the Aeneid in Latin in graduate school (Ph.D. in Spanish Literature) and consult Lewis and Short for the translation of unfamiliar words. That dictionary offered examples of the word in a text, which often was the very verse from Vergil.

I can't really comment on Amazon's book reviews but I do participate in their review system for many other products. I find that in general it is fairly easy to get a sense of a products quality. You still see a lot of 1, 2 and 3 star rated products on Amazon even from big name companies. While I am sure there are shills I think that they get drowned out in a lot of categories. One thing I don't see happening too much on Amazon is censoring of reviews. If I write a well crafted review within their guidelines they will publish it whether it is positive or negative. I can't say the same for my favorite camera store here in NYC which does a huge online business. They have taken to only publishing positive reviews. The lowest rating you will see for a major manufacturers flagship products is a couple of 3 star reviews and they seem to be only thrown in as a token.
